item.title: [NOT] Welcome to /biz/ - Business & Finance — 1 replies
item.content:encoded:
[NOT] Welcome to /biz/ - Business & Finance

Open thread • Replies: 1

OP

This board is for the discussion of topics related to business, economics, financial markets, securities, currencies (including cryptocurrencies), commodities, etc -- as well as topics relating to starting and running a business.

Discussions of government policy must be strictly limited to economic policies (fiscal and monetary). Discussions of a political nature should be posted on >>>/pol/. Global Rule 3 is also obviously in effect.

Note: /biz/ is NOT a place for ADVERTISING or SOLICITING. Do NOT use it to promote your business, ventures, or anything you may have an interest in. Anything that looks remotely like advertising or soliciting will be removed. Begging/asking (including tipping) for cryptocurrencies or asking for money/capital is also strictly forbidden.

Latest replies

60278993
Check the catalog before posting a new thread!Reply to existing threads about a topic instead of starting a new one. Mods will delete obvious duplicate threads and spam without notice.

item.title: [BTC BUY CLI GUI TX] /XMR/ Monero General — 246 replies
item.content:encoded:
[BTC BUY CLI GUI TX] /XMR/ Monero General

Open thread • Replies: 246

OP

Welcome to /XMR/ Monero General, dedicated to the discussion of the world's most widely adopted privacy coin.

XMR payments are anonymous, low-fee, and fully fungible. Users can send and receive XMR globally without having to worry about tainted coins. Battle-tested privacy tech (Ring Signatures, Stealth Addresses and RingCT) ensures that critical TX data cannot be gleaned from the Monero blockchain; the TX history of all XMR users is kept hidden, with TXs being optionally transparent via the aid of a view key.

XMR ensures low TX fees by employing a dynamic block size that can "stretch" to easily accommodate sudden TX spikes.

XMR's mining algorithm, RandomX, is optimized for devices using general-purpose CPUs e.g. desktops, laptops, smartphones, tablets, keeping the barrier to entry low and ASICs out of the equation.

XMR's tail emission - 0.6 XMR per block forever - incentivizes for-profit miners to keep mining, helping boost long-term network security. This constant linear inflation trends to zero and is offset by coin loss.

XMR has proven to be the only altcoin capable of overcoming BTC's network effect by driving it out of the darknet economy BTC dominated for over 10 years. XMR is also starting to overtake BTC in clearnet commerce as well.

If you still have questions, feel free to ask. A MoneroChad will be with you shortly.

XMR Redpill: https://youtube.com/watch?v=wq6w03E2DS4

BUY XMR: https://monero.eco/exchanges/
Crypto ATMs: https://coinatmradar.com/

XMR Resources: https://monero.observer/resources/

XMR Stats: https://moneroj.net

USE XMR: https://cryptwerk.com/pay-with/xmr/

OFFICIAL WEBSITE: https://getmonero.org

MINING:
https://www.getmonero.org/get-started/mining/

WALLETS:
>Desktop
Official GUI/CLI wallet
Featherwallet
Stack Wallet

>Mobile
Cake Wallet
Monero.com
Stack Wallet
Unstoppable
Monerujo (Android)
Monfluo (Android)

>Infodumps
https://rentry.org/monero-explained
https://moneroinfodump.neocities.org

All the steps take a bit of time but it's not complicated. Once you know how everything works it's no more complex than an Amazon order.

You can't force strangers that donate their time to do only what you want them to do especially if it's a feature you can easily avoid.

>why should i trust monero at all

61849859
>>61848827
I feel like most of the older stuff is still applicable since it's just about the basics. See picrel as an example. However I agree that the more specific guides (for example how and where to get XMR) rarely has good pictures. Do you have other bad examples so we can make a list?

>>61849231
>>cant even tell 4channers in a simple format
Five sentences isn't hard if you ask me.
>the taxman who says "gib?"
1. You already need to be deanonymized for that. The ways you can get deanonymized will stay the same. This would also be combated by using an exchange wallet. I'd probably even use an on-ramp wallet, an off-ramp wallet and a holding wallet. This way even if you were deanonymized and the IRS asks for more than what they're allowed to ask (just the income as a number, not the sources or which bank account it went to) you'd still retain your privacy.
2. This is already possible by being coerced through various means. A view key won't change that. This is proven by your next sentence. >Normies fold faster than a wet noodle.

In short: All proposed 'new' attack vectors already exist, require additional information that isn't easily obtained (they tried for years and still couldn't get it) and are easily mitigated.
Additionally, if someone for whatever reason was willing to inform the IRS of the relevant taxes by directly allowing access to view the wallet (which still is absurd and not how it works) it'd be much easier and also less risky.

If you have any other scenarios in which view keys could be exploited which are not covered already please let me know.

>>61847814

Monerochan (mostly AI slop) also doesn't communicate anything about Monero
There doesn't seem to be any good image macros to share from these threads

Interested in how other people view this issue and what kind of material would get the communication standard up to the same level as its founding principles and tech

61856800
>>61856418
>>61856774
Latvia has something called a "tier 3 pension pillar" but once your money goes in you cannot get it back no matter what until retirement and any capital gains are taxed at 25.5% when you start withdrawals.
If your employer matches your contributions from your AFTER tax wages the matching is taxed at 25.5% up front.
And you can only invest in managed funds that invest mostly in Latvian and E.U. bonds - so if the S&P is up 20% this year you will be up like 6%.
Americans have it good, especially with the Roth IRA.

>How the US government or Federal Reserve "values" gold on its books obviously has no effect on the market price of gold at the moment. Disagree?
Correct, simply "revaluing" gold on their books is just an accounting trick and does nothing.

I'm suggesting that the government will effectively devalue the dollar. They've already devalued it from $2000 to $5000. What's two more doublings?

It reduces the cost of servicing their debt by 80% and will happen one way or another as Trump wants yield curve control (lowered interest rates) because they can't allow the US Treasury long rates to go above 5% of it starts a cascade of a debt spiral.

There is NO money in the social security "trust fund" so all the new boomer entitlements need to be covered by money printing.

Much of the government revenue comes from taxes collected from rising equity prices, hence the "Dow 50000" comment. A recession that market corrects, and results in job losses, cuts government revenues while increasing expenditures for supports and stimulus.

We are sailing into a perfect storm.

item.title: [NFT] Thread 61855938 — 8 replies
item.content:encoded:
[NFT] Thread 61855938

Open thread • Replies: 8

OP

Non-/biz/ here, forgive the potentially retarded question. When NFTs were being hyped up as being this revolutionary advancement in...something, there were often claims that owning an NFT of a particular kind or value would enable the holder to access benefits from it essentially in perpetuity. Obviously no one gives three-fifths of a fuck about NFTs these days, but even during their heyday was anything like that claim realized?
>vaguely /biz/ placeholder pic

Latest replies

61856808
>>61855938
in short - yes. either from a check built into a smart contract, a merkle tree compiled from NFT owners at a certain blockheight, or simply a signature from a wallet holding the NFT.

61856244
>>61855938
I come from professional digital art. NFTs were puzzling from the start. We had been selling digital rights via contract for years for free, so the idea of paying for a NFT.. a jpg with no space for PSD data. Seemed absolutely retarded. Only desperate talentless hacks and grifters fell for it.

61856238
>>61855958

Classic dual lands are almost always going to retain value. Personally, if it was me, I would collect Narcomoeba even though it’s uncommon because I love that card and I love dredge.

item.title: [BCH] Thread 61855284 — 3 replies
item.content:encoded:
[BCH] Thread 61855284

Open thread • Replies: 3

OP

Cardanofags Keke'd by BCH. Finally this shitcoin got outed of the top10.

Latest replies

61856803
BCH is nice. Cheap to transfer, nice privacy features (though not even remotely close to XMR), smart contracts on chain for hedging and leverage trading it, accepted almost everywhere BTC is accepted.

It used to have a much better community of devs at some point but the stability it has now also has its merits.

61855345
>>61855284
it was at 12 for few weeks and has been out of 10 for over a month.
you slow or something?
